South Korean Crypto Exchange แจก Bitcoin มูลค่า 95 พันล้านดอลลาร์ผิดพลาด

South Korean Crypto Exchange Accidentally Gave Away $95 Billion in Bitcoin

1h ago//Sander Lutz
bitcoin
AI

Summary

TH

ตลาดซื้อขายสกุลเงินดิจิทัลของเกาหลีใต้อย่าง Bithumb เผลอเครดิต Bitcoin ให้กับผู้ใช้งานด้วยมูลค่าประมาณ 95 พันล้านดอลลาร์ระหว่างกิจกรรมแจกของรางวัล แทนที่จะโอนเงินสดจำนวน 2,000 วอน (ประมาณ 1.37 ดอลลาร์) แต่ทางตลาดกลับเครดิตให้ผู้โชคดีคนละ 2,000 BTC แม้ว่าข้อผิดพลาดนี้จะได้รับการแก้ไขภายใน 5 นาทีและเกิดขึ้นเฉพาะในบัญชีบันทึกภายในโดยไม่มีการโอน on-chain แต่ผู้ใช้งานก็สามารถขายสินทรัพย์เหล่านี้ซึ่งมีมูลค่าประมาณ 2 พันล้านดอลลาร์ออกไปได้ในช่วงเวลาสั้นๆ นั้น การขายถล่มครั้งนี้ทำให้ราคาบนตลาด Bithumb ดิ่งลงอย่างรวดเร็วสู่ระดับ 55,000 ดอลลาร์ ซึ่งต่ำกว่าราคาตลาดโลกอย่างมาก Bithumb ยืนยันว่าเหตุการณ์ดังกล่าวเป็นความผิดพลาดของระบบภายใน ไม่ใช่การถูกแฮ็กหรือการละเมิดความปลอดภัย และยืนยันว่าไม่มีการสูญเสียทรัพย์สินเดิมของผู้ใช้งาน

EN

South Korean crypto exchange Bithumb accidentally credited users with approximately $95 billion worth of Bitcoin during a giveaway event. Instead of distributing 2,000 won (about $1.37), the exchange mistakenly credited 2,000 BTC to each winner. Although the error was corrected within five minutes and only affected internal ledgers without on-chain transactions, users managed to sell an estimated $2 billion worth of the phantom assets during that brief window. The rapid sell-off triggered a flash crash on Bithumb, causing Bitcoin's price on the platform to plummet to $55,000, significantly lower than the global market average. Bithumb confirmed that the incident was due to an internal system error rather than a hack or security breach, and assured customers that no existing assets were lost.

Key Points

  • Bithumb mistakenly credited users with 2,000 BTC each instead of a small cash prize.
  • Users sold approximately $2 billion worth of the phantom Bitcoin before the error was fixed.
  • The incident triggered a flash crash on Bithumb, dropping Bitcoin's price to $55,000.
  • The error was internal and did not involve on-chain transfers or external hacking.

Article

In brief South Korean exchange Bithumb mistakenly credited users with 2,000 BTC each instead of a tiny cash reward. The error was corrected within five minutes, but not before users sold an estimated $2 billion worth, per local reports. The sell-off, only on Bithumb's internal ledger and not on-chain, still triggered a sharp Bitcoin price crash on the exchange. A South Korean crypto exchange accidentally credited users with billions of dollars’ worth of Bitcoin this week, triggering a flash crash in the platform’s listed value of the token. Instead of airdropping users 2,000 won (a sum worth $1.37 at writing), the exchange, Bithumb, reportedly sent 2,000 BTC apiece, users said . That massive sum was worth some $142 million at writing, with Bitcoin recently trading around $71,000. According to local reports , the accidental transfers were made as part of a “Random Box” giveaway, where 96% of recipients were poised to receive the lowest-value prize (presumably, the 2,000 won). Around 700 Bithumb users bought Random Boxes, meaning roughly 672 likely received the erroneous Bitcoin. That would put the current value of Bitcoin accidentally transferred to Bithumb customers at over $95.4 billion. The deposits were recorded only on Bithumb’s internal ledgers, though, and didn’t involve actual on-chain transfers of Bitcoin. The irregularity was detected and corrected within five minutes, the company said today in a blog post . But that was plenty enough time for some amazed Bithumb users to attempt to sell off the funds and make millions off the company’s error. Korean financial authorities estimate that users managed to sell off over $2 billion worth of the phantom Bitcoin in that window, per local reports. Such a rapid sell-off immediately plunged Bitcoin's price on the exchange to $55,000—far below prices on other exchanges, despite the cryptocurrency’s recent downturn . The price of Bitcoin bottomed out around $60,000 on most exchanges Thursday before rebounding to a recent price of $71,047. “The Bitcoin price temporarily fluctuated sharply as some accounts that received the Bitcoin sold it,” Bithumb said. “We want to make it clear that this incident is unrelated to any external hacking or security breach, and does not pose any issues with system security or customer asset management,” the company added. Bithumb further insisted that the chain of events did not result in any customer’s loss of preexisting assets.
